questions.question: A set of acceptable behaviors for using a computer and the Internet.
The act of using others' ideas and works without proper rights or without acknowledging the source.
Mentioning an acknowledgment of the source of used information.
An act of threatening, harassing, or embarrassing a person using the Internet or mobile phones.
Searching the whereabouts of a person you meet online.
The act of gaining unauthorized access to a computer and/or network resources.
A person who breaks into a computer system for the purpose of fixing flaws and improving security.
A person who gains unauthorized access to a computer system for stealing or corrupting data.
Programs that can read keystrokes pressed by a user to steal confidential information.
A network security program that keeps a check on incoming and outgoing information.
A program used to prevent, detect, and remove malicious software.
A type of Internet fraud that aims to trick people into revealing sensitive information.
A fraudulent act of using phone calls or voice messages to steal confidential information.
A phishing technique where a user is tricked into clicking on something malicious.
Any unsolicited and unwanted e-mail.
Sending e-mail that appears to have originated from one source when it was actually sent from another.
Repeatedly sending the same e-mail to a particular address.
Sending requests to a computer resource many times more than it can handle.
A small piece of data that collects information of your online activity and reports to the host.
A law created to protect the privacy of children under 13 years of age.
The act of illegal copying of a software and its distribution without buying the license.
Laws that protect creative works such as books, movies, music, and software.
A word, name, or symbol used to identify and distinguish products of one manufacturer from others.
A legal right that gives the creator the sole right to make, use, and sell an invention.
Non-public information concerning the commercial practices or secrets owned by a business.
A legal right to identify and distinguish industrial objects by their appearance, style, or design.
Any illegal activity conducted through the use of a computer and the Internet.
An act of using the Internet to carry out violent activities causing loss of life or intimidation.
An act of crime conducted on and propagated through the Internet, which may deal in drugs and weapons.
An act of using the Internet to stalk or harass a person by labeling false accusations.
The act of obtaining secrets without the permission and knowledge of the holder of information.
The information about a user that exists on the Internet as a result of their online activity.
A program that surveys your Internet behavior and copies your passwords for illegitimate purposes.
A program that places advertisements in your browser and allows pop-ups.
A malicious program that attacks a computer and harms users' data.
The online communication platform used for interaction, content sharing, and collaboration.
Buying and selling of goods and services online.
Programs used to search information on the Internet.
Legal property rights of creators over their literary or artistic works, music, ideas, and discoveries.
The most common authorization method used to protect a user's identity, data, and information online.
